articles.title: Physicists prove the Universe isn’t a simulation after all
articles.summary: New research from UBC Okanagan mathematically demonstrates that the universe cannot be simulated. Using Gödel’s incompleteness theorem, scientists found that reality requires “non-algorithmic understanding,” something no computation can replicate. This discovery challenges the simulation hypothesis and reveals that the universe’s foundations exist beyond any algorithmic system.
articles.content:
The idea that our universe might be nothing more than an elaborate computer simulation has been a favorite theme in science fiction for decades. Yet new research from UBC Okanagan suggests that not only is this concept implausible -- it is mathematically impossible.

Dr. Mir Faizal, an Adjunct Professor at UBC Okanagan's Irving K. Barber Faculty of Science, and his collaborators, Drs. Lawrence M. Krauss, Arshid Shabir, and Francesco Marino, have shown that the underlying fabric of reality operates in a way no computer could ever replicate.

Their study, published in the Journal of Holography Applications in Physics, doesn't just dispute the idea of a simulated universe like The Matrix. It goes further, demonstrating that the cosmos itself is built upon a kind of understanding that lies outside the reach of any algorithm.

The Simulation Hypothesis Meets Mathematics

"It has been suggested that the universe could be simulated. If such a simulation were possible, the simulated universe could itself give rise to life, which in turn might create its own simulation. This recursive possibility makes it seem highly unlikely that our universe is the original one, rather than a simulation nested within another simulation," says Dr. Faizal. "This idea was once thought to lie beyond the reach of scientific inquiry. However, our recent research has demonstrated that it can, in fact, be scientifically addressed."

The team's findings rest on the evolving understanding of what reality truly is. Physics has moved far beyond Isaac Newton's view of solid objects moving through space. Einstein's theory of relativity replaced that classical model, and quantum mechanics transformed it yet again. Now, at the forefront of theoretical physics, quantum gravity proposes that even space and time are not fundamental elements. Instead, they arise from something deeper -- pure information.

The Hidden Realm Beneath Reality

Physicists describe this informational layer as a "Platonic realm," a mathematical foundation more real than the physical world we perceive. According to the new research, it is from this realm that space and time themselves emerge.

However, the scientists demonstrated that even this information-based structure cannot fully describe reality through computation alone. By applying advanced mathematical principles, including Gödel's incompleteness theorem, they proved that any consistent and complete model of existence requires what they call "non-algorithmic understanding."

To grasp this idea, imagine how a computer works -- it follows a set of defined instructions step by step. Yet, some truths exist that cannot be reached by following any sequence of logical operations. These are known as "Gödelian truths," and while they are real, they cannot be proven using computation.

Where Computation Fails

Consider the statement, "This true statement is not provable." If it were provable, it would be false, contradicting logic. If it cannot be proven, then it is true, which means any logical system attempting to prove it is incomplete. In either case, computation alone falls short.

"We have demonstrated that it is impossible to describe all aspects of physical reality using a computational theory of quantum gravity," says Dr. Faizal. "Therefore, no physically complete and consistent theory of everything can be derived from computation alone. Rather, it requires a non-algorithmic understanding, which is more fundamental than the computational laws of quantum gravity and therefore more fundamental than spacetime itself."

Why the Universe Cannot Be Simulated

If the underlying rules of the Platonic realm seem similar to those governing a computer simulation, could that realm itself be simulated? The answer, according to the researchers, is no.

"Drawing on mathematical theorems related to incompleteness and indefinability, we demonstrate that a fully consistent and complete description of reality cannot be achieved through computation alone," explains Dr. Faizal. "It requires non-algorithmic understanding, which by definition is beyond algorithmic computation and therefore cannot be simulated. Hence, this universe cannot be a simulation."

Co-author Dr. Lawrence M. Krauss notes that the implications of this finding extend deep into the foundations of physics. "The fundamental laws of physics cannot be contained within space and time, because they generate them. It has long been hoped, however, that a truly fundamental theory of everything could eventually describe all physical phenomena through computations grounded in these laws. Yet we have demonstrated that this is not possible. A complete and consistent description of reality requires something deeper -- a form of understanding known as non-algorithmic understanding."

Reality Beyond Algorithms

As Dr. Faizal summarizes, "Any simulation is inherently algorithmic -- it must follow programmed rules. But since the fundamental level of reality is based on non-algorithmic understanding, the universe cannot be, and could never be, a simulation."

For years, the simulation hypothesis was regarded as untestable, confined to the realms of philosophy and speculative fiction. This new research, however, anchors it firmly in mathematical and physical theory -- delivering what may be the final, definitive answer to one of science's most intriguing questions.
articles.reasoning: This article reports a significant scientific breakthrough that mathematically disproves the simulation hypothesis, providing a deeper understanding of the universe's fundamental nature. The research has broad implications for physics and philosophy, offering a meaningful advancement in knowledge that inspires curiosity and hope about uncovering reality's true nature.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’UBC Okanagan, dirigés par le Dr Mir Faizal, ont utilisé une mathématique avancée appelée le théorème d’incomplétude de Gödel pour étudier le fonctionnement de l’univers. Leur étude, publiée dans une revue de physique, montre que l’univers fonctionne d’une manière qu’aucun programme informatique ne peut reproduire. Ils ont découvert que la réalité demande une forme de compréhension que les ordinateurs ne peuvent pas suivre, car elle dépasse les capacités des algorithmes.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car elle prouve que l’univers n’est pas une simple simulation dans un ordinateur. Elle change la façon dont les scientifiques pensent la réalité et montre que les parties les plus profondes de l’univers reposent sur autre chose que des règles ou des codes. Cela remet en question les anciennes idées et nous aide à mieux comprendre comment l’espace, le temps et la réalité se forment.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont continuer à explorer cette idée pour mieux comprendre la « compréhension non algorithmique » qui façonne la réalité. Cela pourrait ouvrir de nouvelles façons de penser la physique et l’univers au-delà des ordinateurs et des théories actuelles.

**Phrase clé** – Une nouvelle preuve mathématique montre que l’univers ne peut pas être une simulation informatique, car il nécessite une forme de compréhension qu’aucun algorithme ne peut fournir.

articles.title: A fault-tolerant neutral-atom architecture for universal quantum computation
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09848-5A fault-tolerant neutral-atom architecture for universal quantum computation
articles.content: Supplementary Videos 2 and 3 are movies of single atoms (real pictures captured with a microscope objective and CMOS camera), showing the quantum circuit implemented in Figs. 6 to realize teleportation-based algorithms in the space and time direction. Parallel entangling gates are indicated by red ovals. Two groups of qubits, A and B, are in the readout and storage zone, respectively, with additional qubits forming the reservoir. Qubits in group A are moved into the entangling zone and encoded using a hypercube encoding circuit. Transversal gates between codes form a 1D cluster state. Next, group B (already entangled) is entangled with group A to create a 2D cluster state, across the space and time directions. Group A is moved to storage, to be entangled with the next cycle, and group B is moved to the readout zone and measured via spin-to-position conversion. For illustrative purposes, each qubit is prepared in \(| +\rangle \) and therefore imaged with equal probability in the two tweezer locations (frames are averaged over several shots). Finally, the tweezers are recombined, the atoms are re-cooled, loss is re-filled, and the qubit state is reinitialized. This is one layer. The cycle then repeats 27 times. Supplementary Video 2: Teleportation-based logical algorithm with Steane [[7,1,3]] codes. Each group consists of 16 code blocks in a 4x4 grid, which are entangled into two independent 1D cluster states (eight blocks each) and further into 2D cluster states with adjacent layers in time.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant breakthrough in quantum computing architecture with fault-tolerant neutral-atom systems enabling universal quantum computation. This advancement has broad implications for the future of computing technology, potentially impacting many fields through improved quantum algorithms and error correction. The detailed description of the experimental setup and error-correcting codes demonstrates substantial substance and real-world scientific progress.
articles.personality_title: New quantum computing design uses neutral atoms to reduce errors
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Quantum computers are machines that use tiny particles like atoms to solve problems much faster than regular computers. However, they often make mistakes because the particles are very sensitive and can lose information easily.

**What happened** – Scientists have created a new way to build quantum computers using neutral atoms, which are atoms with no electric charge. Their design can detect and fix errors during calculations, making the system more reliable. They used special codes called Steane codes and arranged atoms in groups to perform complex operations repeatedly, showing this method works in real experiments.

**Impact** – This is important because fixing errors is one of the biggest challenges in quantum computing. By using neutral atoms with this fault-tolerant design, the computer can run longer and handle more complicated tasks without losing information. This could help scientists develop better quantum algorithms and bring quantum computers closer to practical use.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue improving this design by testing larger systems and making the process faster and more efficient. They also plan to explore how this approach can be used in real-world quantum applications like secure communication and advanced simulations.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have built a new quantum computer design using neutral atoms that can detect and fix errors, making quantum computing more reliable and closer to practical use.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des scientifiques ont créé une nouvelle façon de construire des ordinateurs quantiques en utilisant des atomes neutres, c’est-à-dire des atomes sans charge électrique. Leur conception peut détecter et corriger les erreurs pendant les calculs, rendant le système plus fiable. Ils ont utilisé des codes spéciaux appelés codes Steane et ont organisé les atomes en groupes pour réaliser des opérations complexes plusieurs fois, montrant que cette méthode fonctionne dans des expériences réelles.

**Impact** – C’est important car corriger les erreurs est l’un des plus grands défis de l’informatique quantique. En utilisant des atomes neutres avec cette conception tolérante aux fautes, l’ordinateur peut fonctionner plus longtemps et gérer des tâches plus compliquées sans perdre d’informations. Cela pourrait aider les scientifiques à développer de meilleurs algorithmes quantiques et à rapprocher les ordinateurs quantiques de leur utilisation pratique.

**Étape suivante** – Les chercheurs vont continuer à améliorer cette conception en testant des systèmes plus grands et en rendant le processus plus rapide et efficace. Ils prévoient aussi d’explorer comment cette approche peut être utilisée dans des applications quantiques réelles comme la communication sécurisée et les simulations avancées.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des scientifiques ont construit une nouvelle conception d’ordinateur quantique utilisant des atomes neutres qui peuvent détecter et corriger les erreurs, rendant l’informatique quantique plus fiable et plus proche de l’usage pratique.

articles.title: Could electric race cars soon be faster than Formula 1?
articles.summary: The electric cars of the Formula E racing championship can accelerate faster than Formula 1 cars and their top speeds are catching up – but battery capacity would let them down in a head-to-head
articles.content:
The electric cars of the Formula E racing championship can accelerate faster than Formula 1 cars and their top speeds are catching up – but battery capacity would let them down in a head-to-head

A Citroen Racing Formula E car during pre-season testing ahead of the 2025-26 ABB FIA Formula E World Championship Independent Photo Agency/Alamy

With their sleek lines, smoking tyres and thunderous engines, Formula 1 cars have been the fastest road vehicles for the past 50 years. But electric vehicles may soon become the quickest on Earth, as the battery-powered cars of the upstart Formula E racing championship are making huge technological strides.

Formula E has just unveiled its generation 4 car, which can generate up to 600 kilowatts of power, equivalent to 815 horsepower. This will propel the vehicle to reach speeds above 350 kilometres per hour, up from 320 km/h now.

Formula 1 still has a slight edge with top speeds exceeding 370 km/h. But Formula E cars already accelerate 30 per cent faster than Formula 1, with the current generation 3 going from 0 to 60 miles per hour in 1.82 seconds. And as their power and energy storage continue to improve, the day will soon come when Formula E will be faster around a track like Silverstone or Monte Carlo, according to Formula E CEO Jeff Dodds.

“Over the coming years, the car will have the potential to lap at an equivalent pace to a Formula 1 car or exceed it,” Dodds says. “It’s rather a function of physics as opposed to a function of our expertise.”

One major advantage is that electric motors are more efficient. Even in consumer EVs like Tesla, Kona or Ioniq, up to 90 per cent of the energy the engine consumes goes into propelling the vehicle. Combustion engines can only convert about 25 per cent of their energy into motion, with most of the rest lost as heat. Formula 1 has boosted this to about 50 per cent – by adopting a hybrid engine powered by both petrol and a battery that is charged when the car brakes. But a Formula E car has an energy efficiency of 96 per cent, and almost half the energy it consumes comes from charging during braking.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

Electric engines can generate maximum torque from a standstill, with no time lost to switching gears to accelerate. The generation 4 car has permanent all-wheel drive, with a separate motor supplying power to each axle. This could potentially unlock even better acceleration, although it also depends on the grip of the generation 4 tyres, which are still in development.

Formula E’s weakness is the battery. When it started in 2014, drivers had to swap cars midway just to finish the race. Sylvain Filippi, director of the Envision Racing team, says Formula E could build a 1000-horsepower car today that would beat Formula 1 over one lap. But the battery would die over the dozens of laps that comprise each race.

“We still haven’t managed to put the equivalent of 80 litres of fuel into one battery. It does not exist yet,” Filippi says. “The beauty of fuels is that they are so energy dense.”

The Formula E Gen 4 car can reach top speeds above 350 kilometres per hour Formula E

Formula E plans to switch from a liquid lithium-ion battery to a solid-state battery in the generation 5 car, giving it greater energy storage at a lighter weight. A Formula E car could then theoretically beat a Formula 1 in a head-to-head race, Dodds says.

But even solid-state batteries will never beat liquid fuels in energy density, and Formula 1 could probably win over more laps, according to Daniel Auger of Cranfield University, UK.

“I’m sure they could make a great race,” he says. “But I think we’d still see the case that the batteries would be a limiting factor.”

The question will probably never be put to the test, since the two series race under different rules. Formula E, for instance, doesn’t swap tyres in pit stops and has an “attack mode” inspired by the speed boost stars in the Mario Kart video game.

Manufacturers such as Porsche, Jaguar and Nissan will now begin improving the power train and energy management in their team’s generation 4 car to make it as fast as possible before its racing debut in December 2026.

Some of those improvements could trickle down to the EVs you see on the street. For example, Porsche is now including the direct oil cooling it developed for Formula E in its Cayenne Electric.

Formula E’s speed and performance “proves that electric vehicles can do the same, if not more than what a combustion engine vehicle can do,” says Graham Evans at the business information firm S&P Global, “and yet, at the same time, it can do this in a way that is much more environmentally sustainable.”
articles.reasoning: The article highlights significant technological advancements in electric race cars, demonstrating their potential to outperform traditional combustion engine vehicles in speed and acceleration. This progress has broad implications for the automotive industry and sustainable transportation, showing tangible benefits for society and the environment. The article provides detailed context about the technology, efficiency, and future prospects of Formula E cars, making it a substantive and inspiring story about innovation and environmental sustainability.
articles.personality_title: Electric race cars are closing in on Formula 1 speeds
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For decades, Formula 1 cars have been the fastest racing cars, known for their speed and power. Meanwhile, electric race cars compete in a different series called Formula E, which started in 2014 and uses battery power instead of fuel.

**What happened** – Formula E has introduced a new generation 4 car that can produce 815 horsepower and reach speeds over 350 km/h. This is close to Formula 1’s top speeds of over 370 km/h. The electric cars also accelerate faster, going from 0 to 60 mph in 1.82 seconds, which is 30% quicker than Formula 1 cars. However, battery limits mean these electric cars can’t yet race as long as Formula 1 cars without recharging.

**Impact** – The electric cars’ strong acceleration and growing speed show that electric technology is improving fast. Their engines are more efficient, turning almost all their energy into motion, compared to less than half for Formula 1’s hybrid engines. This progress could change how racing and everyday electric cars work, making them faster and more efficient.

**What's next step** – Formula E plans to use new solid-state batteries in their next generation car, which will store more energy and weigh less. This could allow electric cars to race longer and possibly beat Formula 1 cars in a direct race. Meanwhile, car makers like Porsche will keep developing better power systems for both races and regular electric vehicles.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Advances in electric racing cars are bringing them closer to matching or beating Formula 1 speeds, showing how electric technology is rapidly improving.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les voitures de course électriques rattrapent la vitesse de la Formule 1
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis des décennies, les voitures de Formule 1 sont les plus rapides en course, connues pour leur vitesse et leur puissance. Pendant ce temps, les voitures électriques participent à une autre série appelée Formule E, lancée en 2014, qui utilise des batteries au lieu de carburant.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La Formule E a présenté une nouvelle voiture de quatrième génération capable de produire 815 chevaux et d’atteindre plus de 350 km/h. Cela se rapproche des vitesses de pointe de la Formule 1, qui dépassent les 370 km/h. Les voitures électriques accélèrent aussi plus vite, passant de 0 à 100 km/h en 1,82 seconde, soit 30 % plus rapidement que les Formule 1. Cependant, la capacité des batteries limite encore leur autonomie en course.

**Impact** – La forte accélération et la vitesse croissante des voitures électriques montrent que la technologie progresse rapidement. Leurs moteurs convertissent presque toute l’énergie consommée en mouvement, contre moins de la moitié pour les moteurs hybrides de Formule 1. Ces avancées pourraient transformer les courses automobiles et les voitures électriques du quotidien, les rendant plus rapides et efficaces.

**Prochaine étape** – La Formule E prévoit d’utiliser des batteries à l’état solide dans sa prochaine génération de voitures, offrant plus d’énergie et un poids réduit. Cela pourrait permettre aux voitures électriques de courir plus longtemps et peut-être de battre les Formule 1 lors d’une course directe. Parallèlement, des constructeurs comme Porsche continueront à développer de meilleures motorisations pour la course et les véhicules électriques classiques.

**En une phrase** – Les progrès des voitures de course électriques les rapprochent des vitesses de la Formule 1, montrant une amélioration rapide de la technologie électrique.
articles.personality_title_es: Los coches de carrera eléctricos se acercan a las velocidades de la Fórmula 1
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante décadas, los coches de Fórmula 1 han sido los más rápidos en las carreras, conocidos por su velocidad y potencia. Mientras tanto, los coches eléctricos compiten en una serie diferente llamada Fórmula E, que comenzó en 2014 y usa baterías en lugar de combustible.

**Qué pasó** – Fórmula E presentó un nuevo coche de cuarta generación que puede producir 815 caballos de fuerza y alcanzar velocidades superiores a 350 km/h. Esto se acerca a las velocidades máximas de la Fórmula 1, que superan los 370 km/h. Los coches eléctricos también aceleran más rápido, de 0 a 60 mph en 1.82 segundos, un 30 % más rápido que los de Fórmula 1. Sin embargo, las baterías limitan la duración de la carrera sin recarga.

**Impacto** – La fuerte aceleración y la creciente velocidad de los coches eléctricos muestran que la tecnología está mejorando rápidamente. Sus motores convierten casi toda la energía en movimiento, frente a menos de la mitad en los motores híbridos de Fórmula 1. Estos avances podrían cambiar las carreras y los coches eléctricos comunes, haciéndolos más rápidos y eficientes.

**Próximo paso** – Fórmula E planea usar baterías de estado sólido en su próximo coche, que almacenarán más energía y serán más ligeras. Esto podría permitir que los coches eléctricos corran más tiempo y quizás ganen en una carrera directa contra la Fórmula 1. Mientras tanto, fabricantes como Porsche seguirán mejorando los sistemas de potencia para carreras y vehículos eléctricos normales.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Los avances en coches de carreras eléctricos los acercan a igualar o superar las velocidades de la Fórmula 1, mostrando una rápida mejora en la tecnología eléctrica.
articles.image_prompt: A dynamic, detailed painting of two stylized race cars—one sleek and electric with glowing blue accents and streamlined curves, the other classic Formula 1 with fiery red and orange tones and visible exhaust—speeding side by side on a winding racetrack that blends into a glowing circuit board pattern, symbolizing the fusion of cutting-edge electric technology and traditional racing power under a warm, golden sky.
